questions.text: Do you use a password manager to store your passwords?
questions.explanation: Password managers generate unique passwords for every account, eliminating the biggest security risk: password reuse.
questions.actionHint: Popular options: Bitwarden (free), 1Password, or built-in browser managers
questions.affirmativeText: Uses a password manager for secure password storage
questions.negativeText: Managing passwords manually - high risk of password reuse

questions.text: Do you have two-factor authentication (2FA) enabled on your email account?
questions.explanation: Email is the 'master key' to most other accounts. If compromised, attackers can reset passwords for banks, social media, and more.
questions.actionHint: Look for 'Security' or '2-Step Verification' in your email settings

questions.text: How often do you use the same password across different accounts?
questions.explanation: When one site gets breached, attackers try those passwords on other sites. Unique passwords contain the damage.

options.text: I use the same password everywhere
options.impact: High risk: One breach compromises all accounts

options.text: Mix of unique and reused passwords
options.impact: Medium risk: Important accounts should be unique

options.text: Every account has a unique password

questions.text: Enable automatic security updates for your operating system
questions.explanation: Software vulnerabilities are discovered daily. Automatic updates ensure you're protected from known threats.

actionOptions.text: Automatic updates are already enabled
actionOptions.impact: Your system gets critical security patches automatically

actionOptions.text: I'll enable automatic security updates
actionOptions.impact: Future vulnerabilities will be patched quickly

actionOptions.text: I prefer to review and install updates manually
actionOptions.impact: Manual updates work if you're consistent

actionOptions.text: I'll update monthly or when convenient
actionOptions.impact: Some protection, but delays leave you vulnerable

questions.text: How confident are you in identifying phishing emails?
questions.explanation: Phishing is the most common attack vector. Recognition skills are your first line of defense.

options.text: I'm not sure what to look for

options.impact: Basic awareness helps, but more training beneficial

options.text: I can spot obvious phishing attempts
I can identify subtle phishing attempts
options.impact: Strong awareness protects against advanced attacks

options.text: I could teach others about phishing

questions.text: Do you have antivirus software installed and actively running?
questions.explanation: Antivirus provides real-time protection against malware, viruses, and other threats.
questions.actionHint: Windows Defender is built-in and effective, or consider third-party options

questions.text: Enable full disk encryption on your device
questions.explanation: Encryption protects your data if your device is lost, stolen, or accessed by unauthorized users.

actionOptions.text: My device is already fully encrypted
actionOptions.impact: Your data is protected even if device is compromised

actionOptions.text: I'll enable encryption now
actionOptions.impact: Strong protection for sensitive data

actionOptions.text: I'll encrypt just my important folders
actionOptions.impact: Partial protection is better than none

actionOptions.text: I'm worried about performance impact
actionOptions.impact: Modern devices handle encryption with minimal performance impact

questions.text: How quickly does your screen lock when idle?
questions.explanation: Quick screen locks prevent unauthorized access if you step away from your device.

options.impact: High risk if device is left unattended
Reasonable balance of security and convenience

questions.text: Review and secure your web browser settings
questions.explanation: Browsers are common attack targets. Proper configuration significantly improves security.

actionOptions.text: My browser is already configured securely
actionOptions.impact: Strong web security foundation

actionOptions.text: I'll review and improve my browser security
actionOptions.impact: Significantly reduces web-based attack risks

actionOptions.text: I'll make some basic security changes
actionOptions.impact: Some improvement in web security

actionOptions.text: I'll stick with default browser settings
actionOptions.impact: Default settings provide basic protection

questions.text: Is your home WiFi network secured with WPA3 or WPA2 encryption?
questions.explanation: Unsecured WiFi allows neighbors and passersby to access your network and potentially your data.
questions.actionHint: Check your router settings or contact your ISP for help
questions.affirmativeText: Home WiFi secured with strong encryption
questions.negativeText: WiFi network may be vulnerable to unauthorized access

questions.text: How do you handle sensitive activities on public WiFi?
questions.explanation: Public WiFi is often unsecured, making your data visible to other users and potential attackers.

options.text: I use public WiFi normally for everything
options.impact: High risk: Sensitive data exposed on public networks

options.text: I avoid banking but use it for most things
options.impact: Some risk reduction, but many activities still exposed

options.text: I only browse and check email on public WiFi
options.impact: Good practice for most sensitive activities

options.text: I use a VPN on all public WiFi
options.impact: Excellent: All traffic encrypted on public networks

questions.explanation: Backups protect against ransomware, hardware failure, theft, and accidental deletion.

actionOptions.impact: Strong protection against data loss

actionOptions.impact: Strong protection against information gathering

actionOptions.text: I'll review and improve all my social media privacy
actionOptions.impact: Significantly reduces information exposure

actionOptions.impact: Good protection for primary accounts
